{{Short description|American lacrosse player}} {{About|the lacrosse player|the musician of the same name|Andrew Combs (musician)}} {{Infobox lacrosse player | position = Attack | shoots = | height_ft = 5 | height_in = 10 | weight_lb = 175 | nll_team = | former_nll_teams = | mll_team = [[Washington Bayhawks]] | former_mll_teams = [[Los Angeles Riptide]]
[[Baltimore Bayhawks]]
[[Rochester Rattlers]] | league = [[NCAA]] | team = [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1977|12|31|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Towson, Maryland]] | nationality = American | nll_draft = 78th overall | nll_draft_year = 2001 | nll_draft_team = [[Philadelphia Wings (1987–2014)|Philadelphia Wings]] | career_start = [[2003 MLL season|2003]] | nickname = Buggs }} '''Andrew 'Buggs' Combs''' (born December 31, 1977) is a former American professional [[lacrosse]] player. He attended the [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]], and played with the [[Chesapeake Bayhawks]] of the [[Major League Lacrosse]].[http://thebayhawks.com/team/roster/index.html?player_id=56 Chesapeake Bayhawks Website] Andrew Combs' Bayhawks Bio Combs is currently a head lacrosse coach for the API Diamondbacks Lacrosse Club in Gambrills, Maryland for Athletic Performance Incorporated. Combs was the Offensive Coordinator, under head coach Tony Seaman, for the [[Towson University]] Men's Lacrosse team.[http://towsontigers.com/sports/mlacrosse/coach/bio.asp?COACH_ID=22 Towson University Athletics Website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070822135227/http://towsontigers.com/sports/mlacrosse/coach/bio.asp?COACH_ID=22 |date=August 22, 2007 }} Andrew Combs' Coach Bio == Professional career == '''2007:''' Began the season with the [[Los Angeles Riptide]] where he played in three games and recorded 13 goals and 1 assist. Traded to the [[Washington Bayhawks]] and played in seven games at attack in which he scored 9 goals and 1 assist for 10 points. Finished the season with 22 total goals. '''2006:''' Was traded to the Riptide from the [[Rochester Rattlers]]. Was named the Offensive Player of the Week during weeks 9 and 11. Was named the Bud Light Game MVP on July 23. Played in 12 games and scored in 11, tallying 27 goals and 3 assists for 30 points while picking up 9 ground balls. '''2005:''' Played in 6 games for the [[Rochester Rattlers]], scoring in all 6 games. Tallied 17 goals and had 3 assists for 20 points while recording 7 ground balls. Was named the [[Major League Lacrosse Most Improved Player of the Year Award]].[http://www.lariptide.com/team/Roster/?id=487 Los Angeles Riptide Website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070525204052/http://www.lariptide.com/team/Roster/?id=487 |date=May 25, 2007 }} Andrew Combs' Player Bio and named the Offensive Player of the Week in week 9. '''2004:''' Played two games for the Baltimore Bayhawks, recording 4 ground balls and 4 shots. '''2003:''' Played in 7 games as a rookie for the Baltimore Bayhawks. Tallied 8 goals and 1 assist for 9 points while picking up 9 ground balls. Combs also plays lacrosse for the storied amateur [[Mount Washington Lacrosse Club]].[http://mwcwolfpack.org/5.html 2009 Team Roster] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727103414/http://mwcwolfpack.org/5.html |date=July 27, 2011 }}, Mount Washington Lacrosse Club, retrieved May 26, 2010. == College career == Combs played [[college lacrosse]] at the [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]] becoming the second Terrapin player ever to score 50 goals in a single season during his senior year. He earned National Player of the Week, first team All-ACC, and second team All-American honors during his senior season in which he scored 56 total points. He led the [[Atlantic Coast Conference|ACC]] in goals per game average with 3.13 per game. He’s currently ranked 15th all time on the Terrapins career goals list with 87.{{cite web|url=https://umterps.com/news/2013/4/9/208120710.aspx|title=Andrew Combs Bio|publisher=University of Maryland|date=April 9, 2013}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Combs, Andrew}} [[Category:1977 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American lacrosse players]] [[Category:Chesapeake Bayhawks players]] [[Category:Major League Lacrosse major award winners]] [[Category:Major League Lacrosse players]] [[Category:Maryland Terrapins men's lacrosse players]] [[Category:Mount Washington Lacrosse Club players]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Towson, Maryland]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Baltimore County, Maryland]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Maryland]] [[Category:Towson Tigers men's lacrosse coaches]] [[Category:University of Maryland, College Park alumni]]

{{short description|American singer-songwriter}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Andrew Combs | image = Andrew Combs 2018 2.jpg | caption = Combs performing at the Heartland Festival in the Netherlands in 2018 | image_size = | landscape = no | birth_name = Andrew Warriner Combs | alias = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1986|12|19}} | birth_place = [[Dallas, Texas]], United States | origin = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], United States | death_date = | instrument = Vocals, guitar | genre = [[country music|Country]], [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[Folk music|Folk]] | occupation = Musician, singer-songwriter | years_active = | label = [[Loose Music]] (Europe), [[SESAC]], Coin Records | associated_acts = | website = {{Official website}} }} '''Andrew Warriner Combs'''{{cite web|url=https://www.ascap.com/repertory#/ace/search/workID/906071628 |title=HIDE AND SEEK |website=ASCAP |publisher=American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers |access-date=March 13, 2023}} is an American singer, songwriter, and guitarist from [[Dallas, Texas]], who currently resides in [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. ==Career== Andrew Combs released his debut [[Extended play|EP]], ''Tennessee Time'', in May 2010, which has been compared to [[Mickey Newbury]] and [[Guy Clark]].{{cite web | url = http://www.americansongwriter.com/2010/07/andrew-combs-tennessee-time/ | title = Andrew Combs: Tennessee Time | magazine = [[American Songwriter]] | first = David | last = Inman | date = July 27, 2010 | publisher = ForASong Media, LLC | access-date = June 1, 2015}} In April 2012, Combs released a vinyl 7-inch called "Big Bad Love".{{cite web | url = http://www.nashvillescene.com/nashvillecream/archives/2012/04/10/pre-order-andrew-combs-big-bad-love-7-inch-hear-big-bad-love-and-take-it-from-me-now-fresh-tracks/ | first = D. Patrick | last = Rodgers | title = Pre-Order Andrew Combs' 'Big Bad Love' 7-Inch | date = April 10, 2012 | website = Nashville Scene | via = Nashvillescene.com | access-date = June 1, 2015}} In July 2012, Combs signed to the Nashville-based music publishing arm of New York City record label, [[Razor & Tie]].{{cite web | url = http://www.razorandtiemusicpublishing.com/artist/andrew-combs | archive-url = https://archive.today/20130201013506/http://www.razorandtiemusicpublishing.com/artist/andrew-combs | archive-date = February 1, 2013 | title = Razor & Tie artist page: Andrew Combs | publisher = Razorandtiemuscipublishing.com | access-date = June 1, 2015 | url-status = dead}} In October 2012, Combs released ''Worried Man'', which ''American Songwriter'' gave a 4-star review, writing: "As singer/songwriter first albums go, it'll be tough to beat this as one of the years finest, from a newcomer who is hopefully just tapping into his talent."{{cite magazine | url = http://www.americansongwriter.com/2012/10/andrew-combs-worried-man/ | title = Andrew Combs: Worried Man | first = Hal | last = Horowitz | magazine = [[American Songwriter]] | date = October 30, 2012 | publisher = ForASong Media, LLC | access-date = June 1, 2015}} In 2013, Combs supported [[Shovels & Rope]] and [[Caitlin Rose]] on national tours{{cite web | url = http://www.songkick.com/artists/3428966-andrew-combs/gigography | title = Andrew Combs: Gigography | website = Songkick | via = Songkick.com | access-date = June 1, 2015}} and performed at the Newport Folk Festival{{cite web | url = http://www.newportfolkfest.net/lineup/saturday/joe-fletcher | title = Nashville to Newport 2013 | publisher = NewporfFolkfest.net | access-date = June 1, 2015 | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130902023409/http://www.newportfolkfest.net/lineup/saturday/joe-fletcher | archive-date = September 2, 2013 }} In 2015, Combs released ''All These Dreams'', his second studio album. In 2016, he performed on the main stage at the [[C2C: Country to Country|Country to Country festival]] in the UK alongside [[Chris Stapleton]], [[Kacey Musgraves]] and [[Eric Church]]. In 2022, Combs performed on the first compilation released by 3Sirens, an East Nashville based indie label founded by [[The Grahams]].{{Cite web|date=2022-06-24 |title=From Their Secret Studio in Nashville, The Grahams Cultivate a Community |url=https://thebluegrasssituation.com/read/from-their-secret-studio-in-nashville-the-grahams-cultivate-a-community/ |access-date=2023-12-11 |website=The Bluegrass Situation |language=en-US}} Appearing alongside [[Dylan LeBlanc]], [[The Grahams]] and [[Caitlin Rose]], Combs recorded a cover of Radiohead's 'High and Dry' for the special release.{{Cite web |date=2022-09-27 |title=Album Review: Andrew Combs - Sundays - |url=https://music.mxdwn.com/2022/09/27/reviews/album-review-andrew-combs-sundays/ |access-date=2023-12-11 |website=mxdwn Music |language=en-US}} ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable" |- !
